source.document_id: The utility of bronchoscopy in immunocompromised patients

metadata.title: The utility of bronchoscopy in immunocompromised patients: a review

sections.abstract: Bronchoscopy is an important tool for the diagnosis of pulmonary disorders in immunocompromised patients. The addition of biopsies to bronchoalveolar lavage improves the diagnostic yield of non-infectious etiologies, although the underlying etiology of the immunocompromised state must be considered and may be influential. Certain unknowns remain, including timing of bronchoscopy and its impact on medical management and mortality. The ongoing role of non-invasive testing for infectious complications prior to bronchoscopy also remains to be defined. This review addresses the role of bronchoscopy in immunocompromised states related to underlying hematologic malignancies, prescription drug use or chemotherapy, and other disorders that predispose patients to infectious or non-infectious pulmonary diseases.
sections.methods: Narrative review of the literature on bronchoscopy in immunocompromised patients; methods for literature identification and selection were not systematically described in the article.
sections.results: Across immunocompromised populations (solid organ transplant, hematopoietic stem cell transplant, hematologic malignancy/neutropenia, HIV, medication- or chemotherapy-induced immunosuppression, and primary immunodeficiency), bronchoscopy diagnostic yields generally range from approximately 27% to 70%. Addition of transbronchial biopsy (TBB) to bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) improves yield for non-infectious etiologies but may increase complications. Early bronchoscopy (within 24 hours) after presentation is associated with higher diagnostic yield than later procedures in HSCT cohorts. In a large multinational observational ICU cohort (n=1,611) of immunocompromised patients with acute respiratory failure, bronchoscopy (n=618) achieved an adjusted diagnostic yield of 27% (165/618) and therapeutic yield of 38% (236/618), but was associated with worsening respiratory status in 11% (69/618), higher ICU mortality (40% vs. 28%, p<0.0001) and hospital mortality (49% vs. 41%, p=0.003) compared with non-invasive testing. Management changes after bronchoscopy vary widely (approximately 20%-70%) across studies and settings. In HIV, BAL yields for bacterial infection can be as high as 96% (higher if performed before antibiotics), and PJP detection on BAL is 96%-98% without additional benefit from TBB. Complications of bronchoscopy may occur in up to 50% of patients in some series.

population.text: Immunocompromised patients with suspected pulmonary complications (infectious and non-infectious).
inclusion_criteria: HIV infection with CD4 T-lymphocyte count <200 cells/mm3
Prednisone (or equivalent) ≥20 mg daily for ≥14 days
Use of biologic immune modulator therapy (e.g., rituximab, TNF-alpha blockers)
Primary immunodeficiency disorders (e.g., immunoglobulin/complement deficiencies, phagocytic cell defects, DiGeorge syndrome, Wiskott-Aldrich, SCID)
exclusion_criteria: Not explicitly specified in the review

intervention.details: Diagnostic bronchoscopy including bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL); optional transbronchial biopsy (TBB), endobronchial ultrasound (EBUS), mucosal brushing; timing considerations (early vs. late after presentation).

comparison.text: Non-invasive testing or alternative diagnostic strategies
comparison.details: Non-invasive microbiologic testing; imaging-guided percutaneous biopsy for peripheral lesions; timing of bronchoscopy (early vs. delayed).

retrieval.summary_tldr: In immunocompromised patients, bronchoscopy yields up to ~70% across settings; early bronchoscopy improves yield, and in a large ICU cohort it provided 27% diagnostic and 38% therapeutic yield but was associated with 11% worsening respiratory status and higher mortality versus non-invasive strategies.
retrieval.clinical_relevance: Findings guide when and how to use bronchoscopy (BAL ± TBB/EBUS) in diverse immunocompromised populations, balancing diagnostic benefit against complication risk.
